channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Haitians, After Perilous Journey, Find Door to U.S. Abruptly Shut
item.media:description: Haitians lined up to sleep at a shelter in Tijuana, Mexico. Some pretend to be Congolese in hopes of receiving better treatment from the Mexican authorities.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: After a trek through Latin America many migrants thought they were just days from entering the United States, but a shift in American policy has left them stranded.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: ‘Doomsday Today in Aleppo’: Assad and Russian Forces Bombard City
item.media:description: The body of a child is pulled from the rubble in al-Marja.
item.description: Repeated airstrikes that destroyed buildings and killed about 100 people came with the threat of a ground invasion, as efforts at the United Nations to revive a truce appeared to collapse.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Syrian Forces Tighten Siege of Rebel-Held Areas in Aleppo
item.media:description: Syrian government forces at the largely deserted Palestinian refugee camp of Handarat, north of Aleppo, on Saturday after they captured the area following multiple Russian airstrikes.
item.description: The capture of a refugee camp north of the city showed that a Syrian and Russian bombing campaign was bolstering the position of pro-government troops.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Rural Indian Girls Chase Big-City Dreams
item.media:description: Shashi and Prabhati Das, in awe of Bangalore, India, walking from work at a clothing factory to their dorm in June.
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.description: Experiments like one in Bangalore, luring migrants to fill factory jobs, collide with an old way of life that keeps women and girls in seclusion until an arranged marriage.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Chinese Jews of Ancient Lineage Huddle Under Pressure
item.media:description: People playing mah-jongg in an alley in what was the Jewish neighborhood of Kaifeng, China, next to the site of the old synagogue.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: A campaign against unapproved religion and foreign influence has turned to a small group of Jews with ancestors who settled in Kaifeng more than 1,000 years ago.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: South Korea’s President Has No Easy Options in Dealing with an Aggressive North
item.media:description: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea in Washington in October. Despite the urging of other leaders of the nation, she has refused to talk to North Korea after its nuclear testing.
item.description: Park Geun-hye could pursue her goal of tightening sanctions on North Korea, from which she may face more nuclear provocations, or she could try to engage its government.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: The Interpreter: In Syrian War, Russia Has Yet to Fulfill Superpower Ambitions
item.media:description: A makeshift hospital in Syria. Heavy Syrian and Russian bombardments of rebel-held areas in eastern Aleppo have overwhelmed doctors and rescue workers.
item.description: Vladimir V. Putin has won Moscow a seat at any table where Syria’s future is debated. But his drive for renewed recognition as a superpower remains unfulfilled.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: Jeremy Corbyn Is Re-Elected as Leader of Britain’s Labour Party
item.media:description: Jeremy Corbyn acknowledged supporters in Liverpool on Saturday after it was announced that he would retain leadership of Britain’s Labour Party.
item.description: The 67-year-old hard-left politician beat back a challenge by members of Parliament with increased support from the party’s rank and file.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Constitutional Court in Gabon Upholds Ali Bongo Ondimba’s Disputed Re-election
item.description: Tensions have increased sharply in the country since the Aug. 27 presidential vote, and it remained unclear opposition supporters would accept the ruling.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: ‘From Paradise to Hell’: How an Aid Convoy in Syria Was Blown Apart
item.media:description: An aid truck in Urum al-Kubra, Syria, on the outskirts of Aleppo on Sept. 20, the morning after deadly airstrikes on a convoy.
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Interviews with aid workers, rescuers and residents, along with video and photographic evidence, point to a coordinated attack by Russian or Syrian aircraft, probably both.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies
White Helmets (Syrian Civil Defense Volunteer Group)

item.title: Canada Today: Taking the International Stage
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and the Chinese premier, Li Keqiang, on Parliament Hill in Ottawa on Thursday. Canada and China are in talks about a possible extradition treaty and exploring a free-trade agreement.
item.description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s debut address to the United Nations General Assembly was well received, even as Canada and China began negotiating an extradition treaty.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Egypt Recovers Over 160 Bodies From Sunken Migrant Boat
item.description: The boat was carrying more than 400 people, most young Egyptian men, and the death toll is expected to rise, officials said.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: 6 Sites Recognized by Britain for Significance to Gay History
item.media:description: Red House, in Aldeburgh, England, where Benjamin Britten and his partner lived from 1957 until Britten’s death in 1976.
item.description: The sites include former homes of Oscar Wilde and Benjamin Britten, and were chosen as part of an effort to commemorate Britain’s gay heritage.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Yumingzui Village Journal: On the Verge of Extinction, a Chinese Fishing Village Resists
item.media:description: Xue Qingping, a fisherman in Yumingzui Village, China, drove his boat from the docks into the bay at dusk so he could fish at night.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Officials, who restricted fishing because of a devastated supply, have tried to promote tourism as an alternative. But villagers say tourists are demanding what the sea cannot give.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Terry Jones of Monty Python Has Dementia, His Family Says
item.media:description: Terry Jones at the Toronto Film Festival in 2012.
item.description: The actor, 74, is best known for his roles in the British comedy troupe and as a director or writer of works like “Life of Brian” and “Monty Python and the Holy Grail.”
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER
item.category: British Academy of Film and Television

item.title: Ex-Société Générale Trader’s Huge Fine Is Cut to 1 Million Euros
item.media:description: Jérôme Kerviel, right, and his lawyer, David Koubbi, on Friday in Versailles, where an appeals court reduced his fine for making unauthorized trades in 2010.
item.description: Friday’s ruling was the latest legal victory for the former trader, Jérôme Kerviel, who won a wrongful dismissal suit in June.
item.dc:creator: DAVID JOLLY and NICOLA CLARK

item.title: Rising Toll on Civilians in Yemen Raises Alarm
item.description: Most of the deaths were inflicted by a Saudi-led coalition that supports Yemen’s president, but some blame also was placed on Houthi rebels.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: The Saturday Profile: An Expert on Chinese Medicine, but No New Age Healer
item.media:description: “Medicine and politics are similar: You don’t blame others, you blame yourself.” PAUL U. UNSCHULD
item.media:credit: Andrea Gjestvang for The New York Times
item.description: Paul U. Unschuld has done more to promote Chinese medicine than perhaps any other Westerner, but he sees it more as a clue to the culture than as an exotic cure.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON

item.title: Sinosphere: Chinese City Urges Comrades to Do Their Part and Reproduce
item.media:description: Now that all Chinese families are allowed to have two children, Communist Party members in at least one city have been instructed to take the lead and have a second child.
item.description: The appeal by Yichang officials, coming so soon after the end of the national one-child policy, was met with howls of amazement and resentment on social media.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Sinosphere: For Mocking a Martyr, Chinese Blogger Runs Afoul of Beijing Court
item.description: The court ordered the offender to apologize for a post that compared a Korean War hero to barbecued meat, and his blog has gone offline.
item.dc:creator: KIKI ZHAO

item.title: What in the World: Australia Is Not as Down Under as Everyone Thinks It Is
item.description: That map of Australia you have? It’s wrong. And the whole country is going to officially relocate north to correct the error.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: What in the World: In a Lab in Poland, Plastic That Can Crawl
item.description: Hit it with a laser, and a polymer strip at the University of Warsaw will start wriggling like a caterpillar, part of a new class of “soft robots.”
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN

item.title: Opinion: Forget Trump’s Wall: For Mexico, the Election Is About Nafta
item.description: With both candidates bashing free trade, how their anger translates into policy is the big question south of the border.
item.dc:creator: IOAN GRILLO

item.title: Opinion: A Humane Voice for a Cruel Regime
item.media:description: Iranians listened to a Friday prayer speech by Ayatollah Ali Khamenei in 2009.
item.media:credit: Newsha Tavakolian/Polaris, for The New York Times
item.description: Dissenters aren’t jailed for their opinions? Iran’s top diplomat must know he’s lying about that.
item.dc:creator: MAZIAR BAHARI
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Brendan Cox: Carrying On Jo’s Work Against Hate
item.media:description: People gathered in Trafalgar Square, London, on June 22 to celebrate the life of Jo Cox on what would have been her 42nd birthday.
item.description: My wife, a British member of Parliament, was murdered in June amid a swirl of xenophobia. I’m dedicated to turning that horror to good.
item.dc:creator: BRENDAN COX

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Postscript: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
item.media:description: Laborers transported ammonium nitrate at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria in April 2015. The compound, a common fertilizer, has also been used by terrorists to create explosives.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Notebook: How Many Guns Did the U.S. Lose Track of in Iraq and Afghanistan? Hundreds of Thousands.
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers after receiving new rifles from U.S. forces in Baghdad in May 2007.
item.description: A new study shows how the American military failed at the soldier’s most basic responsibility: keeping track of firearms.
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
